description: From Middle English canevas, from Anglo-Norman, from Old Northern French canevas (compare Old French chanevas, chenevas) from a root derived from Latin cannabis, from Ancient Greek κάνναβις (kánnabis). Compare French canevas, resulting from a blend of the Old French and a Picard dialect word, itself from Old Northern French. Doublet of cannabis and hemp.

nouns.description: canvas (plural canvasses or canvases) (see usage notes)

entries.meaning: A type of coarse cloth, woven from hemp, useful for making sails and tents or as a surface for paintings.
examples: The term canvas is very widely used, as well to denote the coarse fabrics employed for kitchen use, as for strainers, and wraps for meat, as for the best quality of ordinary table and shirting linen.

entries.meaning: A piece of canvas cloth stretched across a frame on which one may paint.
A painting, or a picture on canvas.
A mesh of loosely woven cotton strands or molded plastic to be decorated with needlepoint, cross-stitch, rug hooking, or other crafts.

examples: The author takes rural midwestern life as a canvas for a series of tightly woven character studies

entries.meaning: (computer graphics) A region on which graphics can be rendered.

examples: He spent the night under canvas.

entries.meaning: A rough draft or model of a song, air, or other literary or musical composition; especially one to show a poet the measure of the verses he is to make.

verbs.description: canvas (third-person singular simple present canvases, present participle canvasing, simple past and past participle canvased)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cover (an area or object) with canvas.

verbs.description: canvas (third-person singular simple present canvases, present participle canvasing, simple past and past participle canvased)
